an5.33:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bhaddiye viharati jātiyā vane.
an5.33:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Bhaddiya, in Jātiyā Wood.

an5.33:1.2.pli: Atha kho uggaho meṇḍakanattā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggaho meṇḍakanattā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.33:1.2.eng: Then Uggaha, Meṇḍaka’s grandson, went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an5.33:2.1.pli: “Adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya attacatuttho bhattan”ti.
an5.33:2.1.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me, together with three other monks.”

an5.33:2.3.pli: Atha kho uggaho meṇḍakanattā bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
an5.33:2.3.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Uggaha got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

an5.33:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena uggahassa meṇḍakanattuno nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an5.33:3.1.eng: Then when the night had passed, the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Uggaha’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out.

an5.33:3.2.pli: Atha kho uggaho meṇḍakanattā bhagavantaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
an5.33:3.2.eng: Then Uggaha served and satisfied the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

an5.33:3.3.pli: Atha kho uggaho meṇḍakanattā bhagavantaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
an5.33:3.3.eng: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Uggaha sat down to one side,

an5.33:3.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho uggaho meṇḍakanattā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

an5.33:3.5.eng: “Sir, these girls of mine will be going to their husbands’ families.

an5.33:3.7.pli: anusāsatu tāsaṃ, bhante, bhagavā, yaṃ tāsaṃ assa dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
an5.33:3.7.eng: and instruct them. It will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”

an5.33:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tā kumāriyo etadavoca:
an5.33:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha said to those girls:

an5.33:4.2.eng: “So, girls, you should train like this:

an5.33:4.3.pli: ‘yassa vo mātāpitaro bhattuno dassanti atthakāmā hitesino anukampakā anukampaṃ upādāya, tassa bhavissāma pubbuṭṭhāyiniyo pacchānipātiniyo kiṅkārapaṭissāviniyo manāpacāriniyo piyavādiniyo’ti.
an5.33:4.3.eng: ‘Our parents will give us to a husband wanting what’s best, out of kindness and sympathy. We will get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.’

an5.33:5.1.eng: So, girls, you should train like this:

an5.33:5.2.pli: ‘ye te bhattu garuno bhavissanti mātāti vā pitāti vā samaṇabrāhmaṇāti vā, te sakkarissāma garuṃ karissāma mānessāma pūjessāma abbhāgate ca āsanodakena paṭipūjessāmā’ti.
an5.33:5.2.eng: ‘Those our husband respects—mother and father, ascetics and brahmins—we will honor, respect, revere, and venerate, and serve with a seat and a drink when they come as guests.’

an5.33:6.1.eng: So, girls, you should train like this:

an5.33:6.2.pli: ‘ye te bhattu abbhantarā kammantā uṇṇāti vā kappāsāti vā, tattha dakkhā bhavissāma analasā, tatrupāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgatā, alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātun’ti.
an5.33:6.2.eng: ‘We will be deft and tireless in doing domestic duties for our husband, such as knitting and sewing. We will have an understanding of how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.’

an5.33:7.1.eng: So, girls, you should train like this:

an5.33:7.2.pli: ‘yo so bhattu abbhantaro antojano dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tesaṃ katañca katato jānissāma akatañca akatato jānissāma, gilānakānañca balābalaṃ jānissāma, khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyañcassa paccaṃsena saṃvibhajissāmā’ti.
an5.33:7.2.eng: ‘We will know what work our husband’s domestic bondservants, servants, and workers have completed, and what they’ve left incomplete. We will know who is sick, and who is fit or unwell. We will distribute to each a fair portion of fresh and cooked foods.’

an5.33:8.1.eng: So, girls, you should train like this:

an5.33:8.2.pli: ‘yaṃ bhattā āharissati dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā rajataṃ vā jātarūpaṃ vā, taṃ ārakkhena guttiyā sampādessāma, tattha ca bhavissāma adhuttī athenī asoṇḍī avināsikāyo’ti.
an5.33:8.2.eng: ‘We will ensure that any income our husbands earn is guarded and protected, whether money, grain, silver, or gold. We will not overspend, steal, waste, or lose it.’

an5.33:8.4.pli: Imehi kho, kumāriyo, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatīti.
an5.33:8.4.eng: When they possess these five qualities, ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an5.33:9.1.eng: She’d never look down on her husband,

an5.33:9.2.eng: who’s always eager to work hard,

an5.33:10.1.eng: And a good woman never scolds her husband

an5.33:11.1.eng: She gets up early, works tirelessly,

an5.33:12.1.eng: A lady who fulfills these duties

an5.34:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an5.34:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an5.34:1.2.pli: Atha kho sīho senāpati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho sīho senāpati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.34:1.2.eng: Then General Sīha went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and asked him,

an5.34:1.3.pli: “sakkā nu kho, bhante, bhagavā sandiṭṭhikaṃ dānaphalaṃ paññāpetun”ti?
an5.34:1.3.eng: “Sir, can you point out a fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life?”

an5.34:2.2.pli: “dāyako, sīha, dānapati bahuno janassa piyo hoti manāpo.
an5.34:2.2.eng: “A giver, a donor is dear and beloved to many people.

an5.34:2.3.pli: Yampi, sīha, dāyako dānapati bahuno janassa piyo hoti manāpo, idampi sandiṭṭhikaṃ dānaphalaṃ.
an5.34:2.3.eng: This is a fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.

an5.34:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sīha, dāyakaṃ dānapatiṃ santo sappurisā bhajanti.
an5.34:3.1.eng: Furthermore, good and true persons associate with a giver.

an5.34:3.2.pli: Yampi, sīha, dāyakaṃ dānapatiṃ santo sappurisā bhajanti, idampi sandiṭṭhikaṃ dānaphalaṃ.
an5.34:3.2.eng: This is another fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.

an5.34:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sīha, dāyakassa dānapatino kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
an5.34:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a giver gains a good reputation.

an5.34:4.2.pli: Yampi, sīha, dāyakassa dānapatino kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati, idampi sandiṭṭhikaṃ dānaphalaṃ.
an5.34:4.2.eng: This is another fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.

an5.34:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sīha, dāyako dānapati yaṃ yadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ—visārado upasaṅkamati amaṅkubhūto.
an5.34:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a giver enters any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

an5.34:5.2.pli: Yampi, sīha, dāyako dānapati yaṃ yadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ—visārado upasaṅkamati amaṅkubhūto, idampi sandiṭṭhikaṃ dānaphalaṃ.
an5.34:5.2.eng: This is another fruit of giving that’s apparent in the present life.

an5.34:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, sīha, dāyako dānapati kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.34:6.1.eng: Furthermore, when a giver’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.34:6.2.pli: Yampi, sīha, dāyako dānapati kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, idaṃ samparāyikaṃ dānaphalan”ti.
an5.34:6.2.eng: This is a fruit of giving to do with lives to come.”

an5.34:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, sīho senāpati bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an5.34:7.1.eng: When he said this, General Sīha said to the Buddha,

an5.34:7.2.pli: “yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā cattāri sandiṭṭhikāni dānaphalāni akkhātāni, nāhaṃ ettha bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmi; ahaṃ petāni jānāmi.
an5.34:7.2.eng: “When it comes to those four fruits of giving that are apparent in the present life, I don’t have to rely on faith in the Buddha, for I know them too.

an5.34:7.3.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati bahuno janassa piyo manāpo.
an5.34:7.3.eng: I’m a giver, a donor, and am dear and beloved to many people.

an5.34:7.4.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati; maṃ santo sappurisā bhajanti.
an5.34:7.4.eng: I’m a giver, and good and true persons associate with me.

an5.34:7.5.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati; mayhaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato: ‘sīho senāpati dāyako kārako saṅghupaṭṭhāko’ti.
an5.34:7.5.eng: I’m a giver, and I have this good reputation: ‘General Sīha gives, serves, and attends on the Saṅgha.’

an5.34:7.6.pli: Ahaṃ, bhante, dāyako dānapati yaṃ yadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamāmi—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ yadi gahapatiparisaṃ yadi samaṇaparisaṃ—visārado upasaṅkamāmi amaṅkubhūto.
an5.34:7.6.eng: I’m a giver, and I enter any kind of assembly bold and assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

an5.34:7.7.pli: Yānimāni, bhante, bhagavatā cattāri sandiṭṭhikāni dānaphalāni akkhātāni, nāhaṃ ettha bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmi; ahaṃ petāni jānāmi.
an5.34:7.7.eng: When it comes to these four fruits of giving that are apparent in the present life, I don’t have to rely on faith in the Buddha, for I know them too.

an5.34:7.8.pli: Yañca kho maṃ, bhante, bhagavā evamāha:

an5.34:7.9.pli: ‘dāyako, sīha, dānapati kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjatī’ti, etāhaṃ na jānāmi; ettha ca panāhaṃ bhagavato saddhāya gacchāmī”ti.
an5.34:7.9.eng: ‘When a giver’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ I don’t know this, so I have to rely on faith in the Buddha.”

an5.34:7.10.eng: “That’s so true, Sīha! That’s so true!

an5.34:7.11.pli: Dāyako dānapati kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjatīti.
an5.34:7.11.eng: When a giver’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.34:8.1.pli: Dadaṃ piyo hoti bhajanti naṃ bahū,
an5.34:8.1.eng: Giving, you’re loved and befriended by many people.

an5.34:8.2.eng: You get a good reputation, and your fame grows.

an5.34:8.3.eng: A generous man enters an assembly

an5.34:9.1.eng: So an astute person, seeking happiness, <j>would give gifts,

an5.34:9.2.eng: having driven out the stain of stinginess.

an5.34:9.3.eng: They live long in the Third Heaven,

an5.34:9.4.eng: enjoying the company of the gods.

an5.34:10.1.eng: Having taken the opportunity to do good, <j>when they pass from here

an5.34:10.2.eng: they wander radiant in the Garden of Delight.

an5.34:10.3.eng: There they delight, rejoice, and enjoy themselves,

an5.34:10.4.eng: provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.

an5.34:10.5.eng: Having practiced the word of the unattached, <j>the unaffected,

an5.34:10.6.eng: disciples of the Holy One rejoice in heaven.”

an5.35:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are five benefits of giving.

an5.35:1.3.eng: A giver, a donor is dear and beloved by many people.

an5.35:1.4.eng: Good and true persons associate with them.

an5.35:1.6.eng: They don’t neglect a layperson’s duties.

an5.35:1.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.35:1.7.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.35:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca dāne ānisaṃsāti.
an5.35:1.8.eng: These are the five benefits of giving.

an5.35:2.2.eng: and follows the way of the good.

an5.35:3.4.eng: the undefiled one is fully extinguished.”

an5.36:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five timely gifts.

an5.36:1.4.eng: A gift to someone setting out on a journey.

an5.36:1.5.eng: A gift to someone who is sick.

an5.36:1.6.eng: A gift at a time of famine.

an5.36:1.7.pli: yāni tāni navasassāni navaphalāni tāni paṭhamaṃ sīlavantesu patiṭṭhāpeti.
an5.36:1.7.eng: Presenting the freshly harvested grains and fruits first to those who are ethical.

an5.36:1.8.eng: These are the five timely gifts.

an5.36:2.1.eng: The wise give at the right time,

an5.36:2.2.eng: being bountiful and rid of stinginess.

an5.36:2.3.eng: A religious donation at the right time

an5.36:2.4.eng: to the noble ones, upright and unaffected,

an5.36:3.1.eng: given with a clear and confident mind,

an5.36:3.5.eng: don’t miss out on the offering;

an5.36:3.6.eng: they too have a share in the merit.

an5.36:4.1.eng: So you should give without holding back,

an5.36:4.2.eng: where a gift is very fruitful.

an5.36:4.3.eng: The good deeds of sentient beings

an5.36:4.4.eng: support them in the next world.”

an5.37:1.1.pli: “Bhojanaṃ, bhikkhave, dadamāno dāyako paṭiggāhakānaṃ pañca ṭhānāni deti.
an5.37:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when a giver gives food, they give the recipients five things.

an5.37:1.3.pli: Āyuṃ deti, vaṇṇaṃ deti, sukhaṃ deti, balaṃ deti, paṭibhānaṃ deti.
an5.37:1.3.eng: Long life, beauty, happiness, strength, and eloquence.

an5.37:1.4.pli: Āyuṃ kho pana datvā āyussa bhāgī hoti dibbassa vā mānusassa vā;
an5.37:1.4.eng: Giving long life, they have long life as a god or human.

an5.37:1.5.pli: vaṇṇaṃ datvā vaṇṇassa bhāgī hoti dibbassa vā mānusassa vā;
an5.37:1.5.eng: Giving beauty, they have beauty as a god or human.

an5.37:1.6.pli: sukhaṃ datvā sukhassa bhāgī hoti dibbassa vā mānusassa vā;
an5.37:1.6.eng: Giving happiness, they have happiness as a god or human.

an5.37:1.7.pli: balaṃ datvā balassa bhāgī hoti dibbassa vā mānusassa vā;
an5.37:1.7.eng: Giving strength, they have strength as a god or human.

an5.37:1.8.pli: paṭibhānaṃ datvā paṭibhānassa bhāgī hoti dibbassa vā mānusassa vā.
an5.37:1.8.eng: Giving eloquence, they are eloquent as a god or human.

an5.37:1.9.pli: Bhojanaṃ, bhikkhave, dadamāno dāyako paṭiggāhakānaṃ imāni pañca ṭhānāni detīti.
an5.37:1.9.eng: When a giver gives food, they give the recipients five things.

an5.37:2.1.eng: Being attentive, one is a giver of life, strength,

an5.38:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a faithful gentleman gets five benefits.

an5.38:1.3.pli: Ye te, bhikkhave, loke santo sappurisā te saddhaññeva paṭhamaṃ anukampantā anukampanti, no tathā assaddhaṃ;
an5.38:1.3.eng: The true persons in the world show sympathy first to the faithful, not so much to the unfaithful.

an5.38:1.4.pli: saddhaññeva paṭhamaṃ upasaṅkamantā upasaṅkamanti, no tathā assaddhaṃ;
an5.38:1.4.eng: They first approach the faithful, not so much the unfaithful.

an5.38:1.5.pli: saddhaññeva paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhantā paṭiggaṇhanti, no tathā assaddhaṃ;
an5.38:1.5.eng: They first receive alms from the faithful, not so much the unfaithful.

an5.38:1.6.pli: saddhaññeva paṭhamaṃ dhammaṃ desentā desenti, no tathā assaddhaṃ;
an5.38:1.6.eng: They first teach Dhamma to the faithful, not so much the unfaithful.

an5.38:1.7.pli: saddho kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.38:1.7.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, the faithful are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.38:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca saddhe kulaputte ānisaṃsā.
an5.38:1.8.eng: A faithful gentleman gets these five benefits.

an5.38:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, subhūmiyaṃ catumahāpathe mahānigrodho samantā pakkhīnaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ hoti;
an5.38:2.1.eng: Suppose there was a great banyan tree at a level crossroads. It would become a refuge for birds from all around.

an5.38:2.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, saddho kulaputto bahuno janassa paṭisaraṇaṃ hoti bhikkhūnaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ upāsakānaṃ upāsikānanti.
an5.38:2.2.eng: In the same way, a faithful gentleman becomes a refuge for many people—monks, nuns, laywomen, and laymen.

an5.38:3.1.eng: With its branches, leaves, and fruit,

an5.38:3.2.eng: a great tree with its strong trunk,

an5.38:4.3.eng: Those that need shade go in the shade,

an5.38:4.4.eng: those that need fruit enjoy the fruit.

an5.38:6.1.eng: Those free of greed, freed of hate,

an5.38:6.3.eng: fields of merit for the world,

an5.38:7.4.eng: the undefiled one is fully extinguished.”

an5.39:1.1.pli: “Pañcimāni, bhikkhave, ṭhānāni sampassantā mātāpitaro puttaṃ icchanti kule jāyamānaṃ.
an5.39:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, parents see five reasons to wish for the birth of a child in the family.

an5.39:1.3.eng: Since we looked after them, they’ll look after us.

an5.39:1.4.eng: They’ll do their duty for us.

an5.39:1.6.eng: They’ll take care of the inheritance.

an5.39:1.7.pli: atha vā pana petānaṃ kālaṅkatānaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ anuppadassatīti.
an5.39:1.7.eng: Or else when we have passed away they’ll give an offering on our behalf.

an5.39:1.8.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, pañca ṭhānāni sampassantā mātāpitaro puttaṃ icchanti kule jāyamānanti.
an5.39:1.8.eng: Parents see these five reasons to wish for the birth of a child in the family.

an5.39:2.2.eng: astute people wish for a child.

an5.39:2.3.eng: Since we looked after them, they’ll look after us.

an5.39:2.4.eng: They’ll do their duty for us.

an5.39:3.2.eng: They’ll take care of the inheritance.

an5.39:3.3.eng: Or else when we have passed away

an5.39:3.4.eng: they’ll give an offering on our behalf.

an5.39:4.2.eng: astute people wish for a child.

an5.39:5.4.eng: as their parents did for them in the past.

an5.39:6.1.eng: Following their advice, <j>looking after those who raised them,

an5.39:6.2.eng: the family traditions are not lost.

an5.4:1.1.pli: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an5.4:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.4:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu assaddho hoti, ahiriko hoti, anottappī hoti, kusīto hoti, duppañño hoti.
an5.4:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is faithless, shameless, imprudent, lazy, and witless.

an5.4:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an5.4:1.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is cast down to hell.

an5.4:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an5.4:2.1.eng: A mendicant with five qualities is raised up to heaven.

an5.4:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu saddho hoti, hirīmā hoti, ottappī hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, paññavā hoti.
an5.4:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant is faithful, conscientious, prudent, energetic, and wise.

an5.4:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an5.4:2.4.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an5.40:1.1.pli: “Himavantaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbatarājaṃ nissāya mahāsālā pañcahi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhanti.
an5.40:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, great sal trees grow in five ways supported by the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

an5.40:1.8.pli: Himavantaṃ, bhikkhave, pabbatarājaṃ nissāya mahāsālā imāhi pañcahi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhanti.
an5.40:1.8.eng: Great sal trees grow in these five ways supported by the Himalayas, the king of mountains.

an5.40:1.9.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, saddhaṃ kulaputtaṃ nissāya antojano pañcahi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhati.
an5.40:1.9.eng: In the same way, a family grows in five ways supported by a family head with faith.

an5.40:1.16.pli: Saddhaṃ, bhikkhave, kulaputtaṃ nissāya antojano imāhi pañcahi vaḍḍhīhi vaḍḍhatīti.
an5.40:1.16.eng: A family grows in these five ways supported by a family head with faith.

an5.40:2.2.eng: in the wilds, the formidable forest,

an5.40:2.4.eng: to become lord of the forest.

an5.40:3.1.eng: So too, when the family head

an5.40:3.6.eng: and those dependent for their livelihood.

an5.40:4.1.eng: Seeing the ethical conduct of the virtuous,

an5.40:5.2.eng: the path that goes to a good place,

an5.40:5.3.eng: they delight in the heavenly realm,

an5.40:5.4.eng: enjoying all the pleasures they desire.”
